utterances: Hi.
So this number has particular resonance this week because of all the chatter about Renee Zellweger's new look, right?
Yes, she turned up at an award ceremony on Monday and looked totally different.
So people have been speculating that perhaps she had major plastic surgery, although, she just says that she's been living a healthier lifestyle.
In any case, it got me thinking about cosmetic procedures.
Who's getting them and why?
So I went digging and found this number.
About 18,000 American teenagers got Botox last year.
All right, so that number is relatively staggering.
But did you find out anything about why they're doing it?
I mean, Botox does have some medical applications, right?
Right.
Most of the procedures were probably for medical purposes.
We know that Botox injections can be used for things like facial muscle spasms, strabismus, which is cross-eyes, or even to treat chronic migraines.
But there were still 1,149 Botox procedures that were performed on American children last year for purely cosmetic reasons.
So do we know if this is something that's been happening a lot?
Is this part of a trend?
Well, I wanted to find out so spoke to Chris Simmons, a statistical researcher at the American Society of Plastic Surgeons.
And he said that they're seeing a growth in the popularity of nonsurgical, cosmetic procedures among very young Americans.
On average, they take just 30 minutes and cost less than $400.
So that also means that they're accessible to lower-income individuals having cosmetic procedures.
And that's a trend too.
Households with incomes less than $25,000 a year account for 30 percent of cosmetic surgery patients overall.
Wow.
That said, Botox is nowhere near the most common cosmetic choice among American children.
There were over 13,000 ear surgery procedures performed last year on Americans under the age of 18.
Cosmetic ear surgery?
Yep.
It's called autoplasty.
And it's far more common than rhinoplasty, I've always known as a nose job.
It's also really interesting because ear surgery is a procedure that comes the closest to having an even gender split.
All other cosmetic surgeries have overwhelmingly female patients.
So it's somewhat shocking that all these children are going under the knife, having cosmetic plastic surgery, Mona.
Is there any data that speaks to why it's happening?
And remind us, please, what kind of problems did Mr. Gates have during the last time he went before a Senate panel?

So you recently graduated college, got that first job in the big city, and now face real-world financial difficulties - rent, utilities, college loans, clothes, maybe a night out for dinner, and savings.
All right, forget about savings.
You're barely making ends meet as it is.
Unless you access the genetic ATM, mom and dad.
In an opinion piece in Newsweek Magazine, Melody Serafino argues that the price of that parental assistance is too high.
To be fully adult, she writes to her generation requires financial independence, even if that means sacrifices.
Well, we want to hear from you 20-somethings.
Do you still get financial support from your folks?
And parents, do you still subsidize your kids?
When is the right time to cut the parental purse strings?
Email, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Melody Serafino joins us from our bureau in New York.
Nice to have you in the program today.
Thanks, Neal.
It's good to be here.
Oh, good.
And so, this is an opinion you seem to think is well not held widely in your age group.
The opinion that being under your parents' financial, is that something that you think people...
No, your feeling that to be adult means financially independent.
That's exactly.
I mean growing up for me, what really signified adulthood was being able to cut the purse strings - be on your own, pay your own rent.
And there's you know a certain credibility that comes with that, a certain responsibility, of course, and just a feeling of liberation.
A feeling of liberation.
Absolutely.
You know you no longer have to answer to your parents when you don't have to ask them for money.
You can make your own decisions.
So if you wanted to move to the lower east side and your parents object, so what?
So what, it's your money.
What can they really say?

And the other part of that equation though is that you described a lot of people in your generation, a lot of your friends who do accept money and with it, well, the shopping sprees that you may now have a chance to do.
That's true.
But I think everyone can manage to make it work in New York.
And yes, maybe you have to cut back on some of the superfluous spending, as I'll call it, in order to sort of scrape by.
But isn't there something that comes from that - some feeling of being on your own that is much more rewarding?
There's a discussion going on at Newsweek's website about your column and a lot of people seem pretty annoyed with you.
I noticed that.
But you know what, that's great.
I love the reaction.
It means people are actually being moved by it.
Nevertheless, you also took advantage of some familial help.
You were in a relative's apartment in Tribeca for three months when you first got to New York three years ago.
And well, that's kind of a hand out.
Yes.
Well, what happened is I actually got my job about four days before I graduated.
I had to start immediately two weeks later.
I didn't have a chance to find an apartment, and my uncle offered his place for that three-month period, and that's when I saved my money so that the minute I moved out, I was on my own.
And so you also had a bank account, something you could fall back on, and well, some fluidity, some liquidity if you will.
Absolutely.
You've also said that you do understand that in a real crisis, your parents are there to back you up.
Yes.
I mean that's something they said to me when I moved to New York.
They said, listen, if it ever comes to a point where you need help and it's a crisis, you know you can come to us.
And I said, well, I hope to never let it get to that point.
I really want to make this work on my own.
And that was three years ago, and I haven't gone to them since.
And the source of that decision do you think?
I think it's just the way my parents brought me up.
They always brought me up to really budget my money, be conscious about it.
I've been saving since I was really young, and now I have that savings to draw on should some sort of crisis come up.
Now we would like to get some listeners involved in this conversation, whether you are going applaud Melody Serafino for her stance.
that financial independence is the only true sign of adulthood.
Or if you want to denounce her, give a call 800-989-8255.
Email is talk@npr.org.
We also want to hear from those of you who are, well, 20 somethings, if you will.
And from their parents as well.
Let's see if we can get Jay on the line.
And Jay's with us from Chesapeake in Virginia.
Thank you for taking my call, and I applaud the young lady.
The first thing I thought of when you had this topic was the movie about Joan Crawford starring Faye Dunaway, where she did not give Christina one single dime.
And believe or not, Christina was better off for it.

And I personally do not have any children in full disclosure, however, I do live with two gentlemen that, like myself, are single and with no children but these two gentlemen as constantly asking their parents for this, that, and the other.
And I told them I said, you know, one day, you know, your parents are not going to be there, you are not going to be in a position to take care of yourself.
And for those of us that of your friends, we are going to be replacing your parents as far as giving you advice, telling you what to do and being your safety net.
The sooner you learn to fly without a safety net, the better you are.
These parents that are doing this to their kids, providing for them, they're just crippling them for life.
I'll listen on the radio.
I was just going to point out Jay, that in my experience, friends, though they mean very well, are much less reliable safety net than your parents.
In Alaska, archaeologists have uncovered the bones of two infants dating back 11 and a half thousand years.
Their discovery sheds light on how the first people migrated to the Americas.
Here's NPR's Christopher Joyce.
Scientists say it's a remarkable discovery.
It's incredibly rare.
We only have a handful of human remains that are this old in the entire Western Hemisphere.
Well, the point that I am trying to make is that, the way that I was raised was, I heard when you're 18, you're out the door.
Don't ask us for nothing.
And I believe that my parents, even though they might not have been preparing me for the future with those words of advice, they did me a great favor.
I have learned to do without the things that I would normally be asking other people to help me with.
You just learn to either do it for yourself, or you do without those things.
And I think you are a better person if you are self reliant.
I just do.
All right, Jay.
Thanks very much for the call.
And Melody, you are not going to find an argument there.
No, I couldn't agree more.

I mean, I think that's the real problem is that, if your parents are constantly providing for you, when the day comes that for some reason they can't, you're left high and dry, and you don't know what to do.

And I've seen this problem with my friends where, you know, there parents have cut the purse strings finally, three years after college, and now they can't afford their rent because they've never budgeted for their rent.
And they have to move, and they can't live the lifestyle that they've been living the last three years.
And that gets progressively more difficult the longer this - well, I think a lot of people will call it extended adolescence.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
And I don't think it's the only key to being an adult, but for me, certainly, that was one of main responsibilities of being adult is financial responsibility.
Let's see, we got Sarah on the line.
And Sarah (ph) is calling us from Des Moines, Iowa.
Hi, I realized that I needed to stop taking money from my parents when I realized that my parents needed to retire soon.
I was about 24 years old, and they said we could pay off your student loans but we need to retire, so I'll now take my answer off the air.
OK, thanks, Sarah.
Well, that's obviously something everybody is in a different financial situation, but the financial situation your parents are in is something that their kids should take into account.
